sp.p: Troth Madam, show 'em a fair pair of heels, for she knows you care not for Loveall, so that they conclude it easie to win the old Man to their side, and force you to accept of her Love, as she personates her own Brother; and if so far she prospers, her Gallant is to be shuffled into your hand when the Marriage is design'd, and by that means chouse both my old Master and your self.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Cunningly contriv'd— yet, for all this, I doubt not but to counterplot both her and Loveall too— but for better security, we must be gone from this place.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Make hast then and avoyd the Net; and that you may have time for your escape, I'le in, and hold my Mistress in discourse; and let me know where you intend to be, and I'le send word what passes at home.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: We'le be at Essence's, I have some interest with his Wife, till we have an opportunity to perfect your happiness.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Thou best example of true Friendship.

div.head: Malsey's Chamber. SCENE the Second: Scene a Chamber in Old M. House.
div.stage: Stanly dressing himself. Mrs. Mon. dressing her self at a Table, have Night-cloaths on her head, in her half Shirt, and her Breeches on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Your Raptures are too violent to last— and know Sir, I had not yielded now, had not my Old Man warranted, or rather justified my proceedure; for his Penuriousness I cou'd no other way requite, and he was instrumental to his being a Cuckold, for laying two so full of Love together.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Tis Theodocia, whom I confess next to your self I love, but chiefly for her money; for Madam, you are the sole Commandress of my heart; and that I may hereafter be serviceable to both, so warily I will proceed with her, that she shall only raise an Appetire, which vigorously I'le lay with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Soft Sir, you'le find your stock little enough for her; and for my part, if I cannot hold out, my Dotards Angels shall turn Prourers at my Command; for I must confess the truth of the Song you gave me, which says—

div.l: Who complys with gay Youth, does prudently choose;
She that yields to old Age, does her passion abuse:
She may languish and sigh, but in vain it will prove;
Age, dulls the brisk flames, and slackens hot Love:
He may kindle a fire, but cannot supply;
So, for want of Loves fuel, her passion must dye.
But Youth that's full fraught with Love and desire,
Creates a true flame, and supplys the blest fire:
He'l rally, renew it, and with vigour maintain
What dotage endeavours to do, but in vain.
Then give me a Gallant; when I'm yoakt to old Age,
What the gray-head does raise, his Youth shall asswage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Betty, what news have you learnt this morning?

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Madam, my Master is resolv'd on the Match between Mrs. Theo. and Mr. Loveall, notwithstanding the Letter Luce discovered yesterday, for he has sent for Mr. Loveall this morning; but Luce has been before-hand, and sent Mr. Loveall word that Mrs. Theo. will meet him at Essence the Milliners, on purpose to prevent his meeting with my Master's message, and so hinder his coming hither.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: That was well done— but upon what account is Luce so Zealous in breaking off this Match?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I cannot apprehend the meaning; however, if by her means I gain Theodocia, she shall not want reward.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p:
I must hold this Youngster in talk till my Daughter is Marryed to Loveall; or I'le stand to't, this young Snipper-snapper will, I fear, forbid the banes.
Ha— what do I see? my Wife dressing her self— 'tis too true— absurd, I'le stand to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Cuds'lid, my Husband! what shall we do? all our designs are ruin'd if he discovers me—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'le bring you off, ne're fear it.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Curse on my Dotage; too late I find my folly in Marrying a young Wife, I cou'd expect no less in reason, than to be a Cuckold—
Wife! what subtle damn'd Devil was it put you on this design, to make me the promoter of my own shame?— but Sir, for your part, I'le stand to't, I'le swinge you.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: (Laughs). But Sir, do you in earnest conclude my Bed-fellow to be your Wife?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: A rat on you— Are my Eyes my own Sir?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: No Sir; if you suspect my Friend for a Woman, if he were not, all thy Wealth shou'd not purchase her from my Embraces— here is a Face indeed, as charming as the notedst Female Beauty; but Nature mistook in moulding every part, forgetting she had made a Venus-face, plac'd it on an Adam's Body.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: As I say, if this be true, 'tis wonderful! and indeed, I have often heard my Wife say, that she and her Brother were so alike, (being Twins,) that one cou'd hardly be known from the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Brother, I thought I shou'd surprize you; by my hands, thou art the most credulous man I ever met with— but to convince thee of thy Error— Iack, prithee tell him what sport we have had at Paris in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Yes Faith, my Friend and I have liv'd at least three months upon the Pistols he has had clapt in his hand at Carnival-time, when he went disguis'd in Womans Cloaths, as Earnest, for ensuing pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: But say old Trojan, am I so like my Sister?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Like quotha? I durst to have sworne you had been she.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: To convince you, search me; do, do: but if thou doest not, thy Daughter shall, for I am desperately in Love with her.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p:
Absur'd, I'le stand to't, that I shou'd take him for my Wife— (aside)
But soft good Brother, my business of this early Visit, was partly to deliver a Letter directed to you from my Wife; and partly to desire you to forbear any further amorous discourses with my Daughter, sic volo, sic jubio, you understand me; I have promis'd her to another, and this I resolve shall be her Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How! this day is she to be Marryed? and will you slight Squire Careless? take heed Sir what you do.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Why Sir, I hope you wont Hector me? will you?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: I have a greater respect for the young Lady then—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: You, a respect for the young Lady? what are you Sir, that dare pretend to have a respect for my Daughter, Ha?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: 'Tis no harm Sir, to be Civil to a handsome Lady; it's a Devotion we owe to Beauty.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: But as I say Sir, it is harm Sir, and I'le none of it, therefore show you civility some where else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Iack, no more— Brother, rest content, I'le have none of your Daughter; by my hands not I— for my reasons, see there—
sp.stage: [She gives Old M. the Letter; he Reads to himself.
sp.l: Stanly, have courage, the Girl's thine own,
Since this last rub we have so smoothly past,
All little Oppositions I despise.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: See, see, the Letter works rarely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: It must take, especially as now I have design'd to proceed.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: I'le stand to't, the kindest Wife man ever had.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Now shou'd you kneel and prostrate, Damsel, at my feet, I wou'd deny her; by my hands, not once caress her.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: How Sir, can you so easily quit a Lady you so entirely Love?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: What's that to you Sir: Good Brother rid my House of this Friend of yours, for I fear he'le prove no Friend of mine, shou'd he stay; I like not his Countenance, he has the looks of a slye Rogue.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Rogue! you are merry Sir—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.l: You Lye, y'are a—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: What, what Sir?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.l: What Sir? y'are a Quodammodo, I'le stand to't.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: A Quodammodo?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Yes, a Quodammodo Sir— bring your Action, I care not.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Such another word, Old man, will make me very Angry and Extravagant.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Extravagant! I believe it; but march off civilly, or as I say, I shall civilly make you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Iack, withdraw, and let me alone; I have a Plot which of necessity must be prosperous.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Sir, on my Friends request Ile leave your House, but look to't— a Quodammodo said you!

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Adieu, Huffing Sir— as gad sa'me he has put me into a filthy pet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Brother, I have a rare fancy sprung, which if you approve of, must procure your desire.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: In what good Brother?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: To make your Daughter comply, and marry this Loveall, whom my Sister mentions in her Letter; for since (as she writes) you have promis'd Theodocia to another, I am resolv'd to fulfil my Sisters request in assisting you in your intentions— in pursuance of which, I have thought on a way,— 'tis this,— you say I am very like my Sister?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Right— what then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: How if I, putting on one of my Sisters Gowns, shou'd personate her, and fairly at first use perswasions to Theodocia; but if they fail, to use a Mothers Authority, and Lock her up till the business is done.

sp.speaker: Old. M.
sp.p: How? you personate my Wife! and Lock her up!— well thought on— I'le none of that good Brother; soft and fair, I smell a Rat; I understand you, and so you'l debauch her, if not marry her your self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Who, I? by my hands, all my Courtship was but Rallery a-la-mode.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: But I'le stand to't, you may so a-la mode her, as you call't, that may make her unfit for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: The insupportable censure of impotence! I tell thee old Blade, I'de sooner marry an Orange Wench then thy dull Virtuous Daughter; by my hands I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: A fitter Wife for such wild Gallants, than an honester Woman, Ile stand to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Is not my Reputation at stake? a Sisters Conjuration? by my hands you wrong me, to suspect my Honour.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: But (pardon me Sir) shou'd it come to that extremity of Locking her up, will you neither say, nor do any thing tending to Debauchery, as you hope to be sav'd? gad forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: I'le do neither by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Good; now if you shou'd, I'le Indict you for Perjury, and I'le stand to't; y'are a witty Blade, the design must take, for thou art so like my Wife, that I am almost perswaded to kiss thee for her, but that it is so unseemly for one man to kiss another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Then it is a Plot.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: It is, and we'le about it instantly, the Wench shall furnish you with a Gown— yet me-thinks I wou'd be by, tho unseen to her, when you perswade her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: To show you how unjust your suspition is, you shall.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: (Laughs). I cannot but Laugh to think how the young Baggage will be cousened; you, her Mother?

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: The deceipt will be pleasant, what an innocent Cheat it will be? (to both)— but let us about it.

div.head: Scene the Third. Tom Essence's Shop.
div.p: Well, I find thy soyl Tom, will never produce the fruit of Vallour, therefore I have taken up the safer Cudgells of the two; I have enter'd an Action of Battery against Courtly for violently assaulting the body of Dorothy Essence, my Wife; and my Lawyer tells me, I shall have swinging damages for every bout I can prove he has assaulted her; and to have dammage enough, so soon as I have dispatcht my Customers, I'le to the Temple-walks, and hire two or three Knights o'th' Post, who shall Swear to at least three thousand pounds worth of Trespass, with which I'le buy an Estate, and turn Country Gentleman.
div.stage: Enter Men and two Women to his Shop.
div.p: Fair Ladys, what lack ye? delicate Roman, Italiansscented Gloves, good Essences, Tiberos, Orange Jessamine, Essence d'Espagne, Fanns, Ribbons in every point francois— Boy,— Boy, bring some Essences. (Boy Enters with Essence-bottles) Ha my little Rogues, here are Perfumes— ravishing enough to revive the dead.
div.stage: [He bobs the Womens nose with his Finger and Bottle.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: You are the pleasantest Creature Mr. Essence, I cannot live unless I see you once a week at least; y'are the divertingst person in the Town I swear.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Alas Madam, I, I my pretty hearts; y'are the Diamond Queen of the Nation; say no more, say no more, I have a rich Blade in store for thee; another time, another time.—
Ha! my pretty Cherubins!—

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: What a conceited impudent Rascal's this! (aside. Mr. Essence, a word with you—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: I wait on you Madam— Iack, bring those Spirits came in last from the Iews in the Citty; Rogue, you never mind, never mind Sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1. W.
sp.p: Let me see'em Mr. Essence—

div.stage: (T. Ess. gives 'em about— the Boy imitates his Master.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: There are Scents Ladys— upon Rep— oh incomparable! I can Dine as heartily on a good Roman or Italian Scent, as you can on a dish of Meat— oh lushious! excellent! rare!

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: What do you ask for these Gloves?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Try'em on, try 'em on Queen of hearts— upon Rep, these Gloves are as well worth two Guynnies as the common Jessamine half a Crown; but you pretty Beauty shall give me but an Angel; I be-friend you I assure you; say no more.

sp.speaker: 2. W.
sp.p: Are you Marryed Mr. Essence?

div.stage: [He tryes on the Gloves, pats, stroaks, kisses her armes, and toys all the while he talks.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p:
Yes Madam; yes, I thank my Stars, I am marryed; I was forc't to't, for what with Maids of Honour, and Country Ladys, I was almost teas'd out of my Life— see there,—
a Country Knights Daughter; she has for these two years past, all the time she has been in Town, been as constant every day at my Shop, as a Bully at the Ordinaries; and she makes Love so passionately, that I was forc't to take the opportunity of her being out of Town when I marryed, and so choust her (poor soul) yet she cannot forbear coming still.

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: Y'are very hard-hearted, that cou'd refuse so pretty a Lady; how chanc't you did not marry her? had she no fortune?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, yes, pretty well, some hundreds; but alas, a Country Damsel is not fit for us Traders in this lewd Town, they'd soon find out the fashionable Trade, to our costs— Faelix quem faciunt Madam, I am as to that point wise, at my Neighbours expence; wag your Honour, wag your Arm a little—
But I fear my Town-Soul has plaid me a prank; but Tom. that secret's for thy self alone.
— Ha Madam; how Ceraphically it sits, and for Scent, smell; smell it little Ceraphim.

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.p: What means the Fellow— Y'are Sawcy—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: How? Sawcy in commending my Commodities, pretty, pretty— prithee smell agen—
This, ay this is it y'faith—— Cudslid you Whore—

div.stage: Bobs her, she gives him a Box on the Ear, and goes away with the Gloves. Enter Lov. who prevents T. Ess. striking agen.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How now Tom, quarrelling with your Customers?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Customers with a pox,— I have expos'd to Air, at least a dozen papers of my best Roman and Italian Gloves; smell Mr. Loveall— and the Baggage laid out nothing but a box o'th'Ear; but I had repartee'd it, had not you staid my hand— but Mr. Loveall, I am heartily glad to see you in Town agen, the Ladys have so wanted you at my Shop.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sirrah, will you never leave your Lying to one that knows you? you were a pure Rogue to put a common Whore upon me when I was last in Town, for a person of Quality; but look to it Rascal, for I'le trappan thee into Matrimony for it, and then Cuckold thee.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Say you so, then hang care, I find 'tis impossible to be a Marryed man and no Cuckold, for the Misses who are kept, are more true to their words than the Wives now a days are to their Oaths they make in the Church— (aside. But Mr. Loveall, as I hope to be Alderman, and ride in Scarlet, and have the Blew-coat Boys sing Iordans Poetry before me to the Spittle, I was credibly inform'd she was a Person of Honour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, of Whetstones Park, Moseleys Damsels were Nuns to her, and she was so Pockey, that she embrac'd the offer of a French Vallet to go over into France to get Cure.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: A person of Honour may get a Clap, or so, who can help it— but is she gone to Paris? that I had known it sooner.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What wou'd that have advantag'd you?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Much, much Sir; for I wou'd have sent a Venture by her for Gloves, Ribbons, and Essences: Those kind obliging souls buy three to one Cheaper than your Coy Virtuous Women, I know it by experience; the little Goddesses of Love have the prettiest Wheadlingst ways, that what I have lost by Selling to them, I have choust the Honest Women of— look you— there goes a Rogue who has at least three times giv'n me the go-by for several pair of Gloves— She has call'd in a Coach to see some, fitted her self, faln into a Laugh, pretended business, and made the Coach-man drive away hastily, sans paying a-gad: But hang't, I always got up my loss by the next Virtuous Customers have come, which is the cause of the Report that I sell dear— but Mr. Loveall, I must live; shou'd I be reasonable to the Honest, I shou'd lose abominably.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A precious Rascal, to make the sober Ladys of the Town maintain the Misses: On my Life, this was some thrifty Gallants invention, to mitigate his expence of Keeping.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p:
Upon Rep Sir, my own Invention, to make the Rich Charitable to the Indigent members of Venus-encounters— See, I have a swinging Catalogue of 'em, here, all Debtors, who are to pay trebble for the Commodities they have taken up, when they come to the Preferment of being kept by Lords or Country Cullyes; so that in my own defence,
I'am forc't now and then to top 'em on some shallow-brain'd Lord or Knight, to hedge in my Debts.

div.stage: T. Ess. retires to his Shop.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Laurence, are the Writings finished?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes Sir, they are done, but I having had no warrant to pay the Fees, the Lawyers wou'd not trust.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What's a Clock?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Almost Twelve Sir— you must make hast, or the Canonical hour will be past; and if the old Man shou'd be in a pet, he may chance to stop your Marriage till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fear it not— for I will not sleep, till it be in Theodocia's Arms; let us hast to the Temple for the Writings, from thence I'le flye to take possession of the two great blessings of the World, Wealth and Beauty.

q.l: Whose mighty Charms the World cou'd ne're withstand,
For their joynt powers both Age and Youth command.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: Scene, the first. The Street before Tom Ess. House.
div.p: MY restless soul stung with Theodocia's Falshood, hurries me head-long to a wild despair, yet mighty Love controlls my faint Resolves— but spight of Love, and all his mistick trifling, no longer I'le sustain my Injuries— but stay—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: This Husband of mine is possest, that's certain, and shou'd I be so too, he'd soon be fashionable, which I am resolv'd to make him, if he continues longer in his Whimsies.
— Ha! here's the fine Gallant agen, as pat as may be; well Thomas, look to thy Head, for if this Blade proves kind, something to your cost may follow.—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Marry'd! and broak her Vows! and still enjoys an undisturb'd mind!— she shall not long,— for like her ill-genius, I'le hant her every where with repetitions of her faithless Acts— since thou fair faithless Creature hast rob'd me of a constant Love as thou'st made me, thou sha't be wretched too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Hem— hem, sweet Sir your Servant—

div.stage: Mrs. Ess. sets her self in order by her Pocket-glass.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Oh the disquiets of an Injur'd soul!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: How do you do Sir?— goodness Searches her Pockets, and pulls out an Essence-bottle. defend him, I fear he is ill agen— let me see— oh, here it is,— this Spirit they say is excellent good to dispel Vapours '— Ile try the experiment on him—

div.stage: [take some on her Finger and bobs his Nose.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What mean you Woman?—

It shall be so, I will revenge my self on all the Sex; first force this Tyrant from my soul, then practising dissembled Love, like her, I'le win 'em to my cursed end, and then expose 'em to eternal shame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Upon my life some Ill-natur'd Creature has deny'd his request, which makes him out of humour; but I'le make amends for the rudeness, and will comply if he has the goodness to ask, let it be what it will, for I find I shall not be able to refuse him any thing— Sir, as I was saying— pray how do you.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Fire and Gun-powder! my Wife and Courtly together agen! where be these Catch-pole Rogues now, they might kill him with Authority, shou'd he resist— how-ever I'le in, and fetch a Weapon, and by knocking him down, secure him till they come to Arrest him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: One word for pitty Sir— my heart beats heavily, and I am so concern'd for you, that I Vow I am strangely indispos'd— Oh I am sick—

div.stage: She falls into his Arms, and lets fall the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Ha! the Woman faints—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: The Spirit, the Spirit Sir, quick, quick— rub my Temples Sir, pray do— what not one kiss— (aside. the Spirit agen, and bob my Nose with it Sir—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
Damn her, 'tis Counterfeit— and the whole Sex is
a Cheat— thus Theodocia seem'd, when I took leave of her and left the Town— but I no sooner gone, but she resign'd my Interest to another—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Hold me a little harder Sir— squeze me harder yet Sir; fear not, you cannot hurt me Sir— the Duce take him, he understands me not sure!

div.stage: Re-enter Tom Essence with a Paring-shovel.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Blood must ensue— were he at his Prayers, I'de knock him o'th'head— Cuckold me quotha? a good jest y'saith— but I'le maule his Mazzard, were he as stout as Hector or Goliah— hum— hum,— Valour assist me; Tom, stand to't, and cool his courage in the midst of Courtship— now Sir, after my hearty Commendations—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Curse on my Eyes, what do I see? that hated Fop—

div.stage: T. Ess. offers to strike. Cou. turns. T. Ess. bows & cringes

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Pox on him, his looks make me tremble like an Aspin-leaf: Friend Thomas, thy disgrace will be insupportable; what, Cuckold and Coward too, thy Father was as pretty a spark as e're play'd Tryal of Skill at the Bear-Garden.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sirrah, retire from my sight instantly, or by Heav'n I shall grow wild.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: This is the Kings High-way Sir— winks & beckons to his Wife. and— the Baggage wont stir, ah Gypsie.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Do you dispute Sirrah?—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: I'm gone, I'me gone Sir— 'tis a hard case, a man must be forc't to leave his Wife with her Gallant— but I'le be near to hear and see what you do—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Wherein can I be Serviceable Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Cannot you guess Sir? I am young, have an Ill-natur'd Husband, and I Vow you are Sir— but you'le think me a Wagg, shou'd I tell you my mind—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: No, no, no, speak, what am I?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: You are Sir— Lord I blush so— pray turn your back Sir— you are— pray Sir do—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Torment!— now Madam speak, you are obey'd—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Upon my Credit Sir, you are the most desirable man I ever saw, and cou'd wish—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Cou'd wish I wou'd do— what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Revenge my quarrel on a necessary, but ill natur'd Fool, call'd a Husband—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: To Cuckold him or so?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: I Vow you are an Ingenious person, and guess admirably well Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Oh Theodocia, too late I find the falseness of thy Sex.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Nay Friend of mine, thou canst not want a greater Whetstone for thy Valour than her Impudence.

div.stage: [Offers to strike: Court. turns; he starts back fearful.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Rogue, are you here agen—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: For no harm, no harm I Vow to gad Sir— I only come to pare away the durt my Neighbours have cast at my Door— Sure my Father begot me in an Alarme, for I have fear enough to put a whole Town into Confusion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: My Husband just in the nick— what ill Luck was this.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: That Perjur'd Villain here? how I loath the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Essence,
sp.p: do you tamely stand, and let that Fellow rob you of your Honour?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Troth Mrs. Theo. I cannot help it, for to say truth, I am a very Gyant in thought, but a Dwarfe in action; I understand the Theory of fighting, but the thoughts of blood and wounds have kept me from the practick part, or by this time I had pepper'd him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: So poorly-spirited! you deserve no better Fate— To. T. Ess. False and Inconstant man, are these th'effects of horrid protestations, enough, if broak, to damn thy soul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: What means she?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Madam, in vain you Counterfeit a Passion, a second time I will not be deceiv'd; thou'rt faithless grown, and hast betray'd thy Honour to Eternal Infamy— Oh Theodocia, Reproach me not with Vows, which you, as I thought with as spotless Zeal did eccho to— but now— thy choyce, thy abject choyce declares thy Honour lost, thy former Love Hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Good Heav'n! he thinks to palliate his wrongs with a pretended Crime I shou'd be guilty of— art thou grown so hardned in thy sin, to prosecute it in the face of Heav'n and all the world, and basely to justifie your injuries to plighted Love, wou'd brand my Honour with Inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: to Mrs. Essence. Madam, your Charms do so surprise my soul, that without the blest enjoyment of your Love, I shall be the wretchedst breathing— as now by Heav'n I am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Lard Sir, your Complements are strangely obliging—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Are they so? Very fine y'faith!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: That my Block-head were out of the way now; well I must, I Vow, that's the short and long on't.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Courtship before my Face I cannot bear— desist, or thy speedy death shall justifie my Passion, and thou sha't fall a Victim to my tormented soul—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Good kind heart, how Zealous she is in my Cause still; well— she's an excellent Friend, and a pretty Creature; and had I been as high-spirited as she, the man had been knockt o'th'head by this—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Do, take my Life, and glory in the act, and by one fatal blow, cancel those Vows you made, and which are lodg'd here in my heart Theodocia, then you may uncontroul'd, possess your worthy choyce.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: What a Medly is this? it madds me that I am so disappointed—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Theo.
sp.p: Dont think that this pretended Anger, for I know not what shall excuse the affront you have done me; no, no, a Woman's a Woman, and has a Spleen as well as man, understands points of Honour too; you conceive me— my Husband shou'd be my own— but this lewd Age— yet I'le say no more—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I understand her not— (aside.)— yet too true I know that thou art false—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Witness Heav'n, if I am false, you show'd me the way— but to convince you, here take my Life— and by my death I will declare my Innocence.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Innocence!

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Innocence! a good jest y'faith— when you become the blot of my Scutcheon, and exalt my Horn above my Neighbours; this is Innocence, is it— but Cudslid I'le not endure it— oh good Sir, I forgive Offers to strike Cou. Courtly turns, he cringes. you, upon Rep I meant no harm; be pleas'd to buy any good Gloves or Ribbons, Essences for your Periwig— pray walk in Sir— Pox on him—
Oh are you come, that's well; there's your man, do your Office—

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Arrested! what means this Riddle?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Riddle Sir? you are like to unfold it as you have my Wifes Riddle, Pox on your Learning for your pains—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: What does my Sot design by this? I'le observe, he's such an impertinent Ass, that I am asham'd to own him, for fear this Gallant shou'd have the worse opinion of me for his sake, and disappoint my Expectations—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Rascals, at whose Suit am I Arrested? and for what?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Come, come Sir, I can handle and talk to you too, now you are in the hands of Justice, as they say; you are Arrested at my Suit Sir—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: At yours Villain, Slave, yours?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Even so Sir, at mine and my Wifes injuries, great injuries you have done me, Rep must be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What wrongs have I done thee? hadst thou affronted me, thou art a thing wou'd more deserve my pitty than revenge— and for thy Wife—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Dishonouring her, is I suppose a trivial thing, but now you'le find the due reward for Treachery.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he shall find to his cost, for I can prove three thousand pounds worth of Assault and Battery Sir, you have committed on my Wife.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I injure her! Villain, thou Lyest—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: I swear, and so he does, for he has not done me reason yet, as they say; but if he had, it wou'd have been no Trespass, for I Vow he shou'd have had free ingress, egress, and regress to do what he pleas'd— had you not come as you did—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Cruel Fair, wherein have I done any thing might merrit this ill Usage.
I injure thee! by all that's good, it is as false as thou art to thy former Vows,— oh Theodocia—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Hy day, I talk of my Wife, and he addresses himself to Mrs. Theo—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Were not thy perjuries sufficient—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Leave fiddle faddle Sir, and answer to the point— did you never lye with my Wife, ha? how say you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I never had so foul a thought towards Theodocia—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Look you there agen now— tell not me of what you thought of Mr. Theo. but of my Wife.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Of Theodocia your Wife, I was talking of.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Theodocia my Wife? ha, ha, he; sure the man is madd.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Is not this Lady your Wife?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: A Lady might have been my Wife, if I had been kind, but that time is past.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I am amaz'd! then the Picture I saw in your hand, you had from this Woman?

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Ev'n so Sir— this Whirly-gigg is my Spouse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: He tells you true Sir, and it is as true that I am that Fellow's Wife, a base Rascal as he is to suspect my Virtue.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Virtue! Au Lord! and have been Courted by a Batchellour-spark of the Town! that is the common pretence of all the Whores, tho they have layen with half the Town—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Sirrah, you think by accusing me, to excuse your own base actions; but I'le not bear it, marry won't I; I brought a good Portion, and will be respected and humour'd, marry will I.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Yes, you shall be respected, but— with a Cudgel— if you go on Cuckolding me, I'le tell you but so.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What an unexpected change is here?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
How have I been wandring in a Labyrinth of Errors since I came to Town, and Theodocia's injur'd Virtue strikes such a terror through my heart, that I am all Confusion— Madam, can you pardon one who basely has suspected Virtue and Innocence— some small excuse I have, though not
enough to justifie my wrongs to your fair self; for meeting this Fellow with my Picture which I had given you at my going out of Town, and he affirming he had it from his Wife, and it being reported in the Country that you were Marryed, made me conclude this was your Husband, which made me act deeds I am now asham'd of—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Blest mistake! since it has try'd and prov'd your generous Constancy, and I should rather ask your pardon for having been the Original of your past troubles, tho not wilfully; for Fainting last night at the door, and having your Picture in my hand, I dropt it; but when I came to my self, in vain I lookt, for I cou'd not find it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: At that very time I saw you in my Husbands Arms; and suspecting him for Lewdness, I came with a design to surprize ye together, but ye were too quick, and there I found the Picture.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Au Lord, what will become of me now? the burden of all will light on my Shoulders.
Yes, yes Sir, 'tis too true what the Woman says— and here is the Picture.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Woman, you Clownish What-de-lack? no Woman of your making—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Say you so, then it wou'd have been no news if you had Cornuted me— and I fear the mistake has gone too far for my Rep, pray Sir speak comfort to a Jealous mind; did you not revenge the affront I offer'd you, upon my Wife?— the truth good Sir, and I heartily forgive you, for I was justly serv'd for being such a Coxcomb to conclude what I had not thoroughly examined.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Friend, rest satisfied, I have neither injur'd you or your Wife, but your Jealousie was enough to have made her extravagant; therefore have a care how you provoke a Woman hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Ay Tommy, as this Gentleman says, take heed how you stir up my Granam Eves curiosity in me any more— if you do, I shall be for Forbidden fruit— but I forgive you this time, as you shou'd me, and cease to be Jealous, or I shall be sollicitous for you know what— Madam, I hope you'le pardon my late miscarriage, I Swear I meant no harm, not I, I Vow.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Sir, upon Rep I am oblig'd to you, and now— my dear, let us embrace and sign peace— me thinks this looks like our Wedding-day— if hereafter I break this League of Amity, I give thee free liberty of Conscience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Which I shall take, but till then Tommy, give me no cause, and I will be yours, and only yours, till death, Dorothy Essence.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Well said Chuck— Enter a Boy, whispers T. Ess, Sir your Servant; Mrs. Theo. your Slave: Customers are come whom I must wait on— Mrs. Theo. use my Shop, and pray do you too Sir; upon Rep, I'le sell cheaper to you two, than to any I know, for being the instruments of Reconciliation between my Dolly and I.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Dear Friend, what news hast thou learnt in my absence? does my Father cruelly persist in his design to make me Loveall's Bride.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Madam he does— but what's the meaning of this? Mr. Courtly here? and reconcil'd? by what strange accident were ye made Friends.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Our Stars only try'd our passions by some unlucky influences— but Madam, if you please, we may frustrate your Father's power if you will vouchsafe to make me happy with your fair self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The Proposal's good, embrace it Madam, and put it instantly in execution; for shou'd either your Father or Mother find you, you'd be in a desperate condition.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Mrs. Theo. if I can serve you, command me, and Sir, you too may add yours to hers, and you shall see how chearfully I will obey.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you Mrs. Essence,— and Friend, your proposal corresponds with my wishes,— yet a Father's anger, which will be enflam'd too by a disappointed Step-Mother, may produce a fatal consequence to all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed your Mother is impatient for your coming home, and I have promis'd to bring you; but to prevent all danger, I have contriv'd a way to disappoint your Mother, and Mrs. Essence may be Serviceable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p:
Which I willingly wou'd be, if it be an Intreigue; for I love Intreigues with my heart, and if you please to walk
into my house, we'l discourse further of it— pray walk in Madam— Sir, I beseech you—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Ah Madam, this happy hour will make full satisfaction for our past misfortunes.

div.head: SCENE the Second. Strees before Mon. door.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now for the rifling of Loves charming spoyles— Laurence, have you the Licence ready?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Yes, yes Sir, here is the warrant of Condemnation— and the Writings from your Lawyer; he Swears he has tyed you neck and heels— look you Sir— dear Parchment, to the tune of Twenty Guynnies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Mr. Loveall, your Servant; my Master is in great expectation of you Sir, pray make hast to him, for he is so humoursome, that should you be absent any longer, it may endanger you the losing of my Daughter, and me the Honour of having so worthy a person for my Son-in-Law— which I'le prevent, if possible—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you Madam, and am glad to see your health so soon restor'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Indeed Sir for the present I was Ill, but having taken the Air, and lying out one Night from this close Town—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: In the Arms of your kind Friend Stanly.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: My health return'd, and I was loath to put my Master to charges, which made me put off my intended Journey— pray walk in Sir—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: your Servant Madam—

div.stage: Love and Lau. goes into the House.
Enter Luce with Mrs. Essence Maskt, with Theo. Cloaths on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Here ' s Luce with Theodocia, 'twas well I shifted him off before they came—

sp.speaker: Luce,
sp.p: thy diligence shall be rewarded; Daughter, no words, but along with me—
Now Stanly, I'le perform my promise—

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: So, this was a luckey Conveyance— now to prepare for my own affairs—

q.l: Loveall, at last I've caught thee in my Net,
In vain you'le strive, for you're past retreat.

div.head: SCENE the Third. Old Mon, House,
div.stage: Old Mon. after him Loveall, Laurence.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Mr. Loveall! in good time Sir, I'le stand to't, I have a quarrel with you; what, stay till the Canonical hour be past? Absurd, absurd, I begin to suspect you have no Love for my Daughter; if you had, you wou'd have made more hast—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I Love fair Theodocia?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: As I say, not Love her, or you wou'd have been here sooner; but now Sir I am resolv'd she shall not be Marryed till to morrow; for my opinion is, that all Marriages after the Canonical hour are Unlawful; and consequently the Women are but a kind of Licens'd Whores, which my Daughter shan't be, if I may have my will; I will not bate an Ace of the Canonical hour Sir, I am a Church of England man Sir, I'le stand to't I am.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But under favour Sir, our Church respects not time, but administration; if it be by One in Orders, and according to the Ceremony of the Church, let it be at any time, 'tis good— but Sir, for fear some scrupulous man shou'd refuse, what think you of taking a Coach to Pancras-Church, there it will be done effectually, for that is a place of Priviledge and Liberty to Marry without Lincenses, and at any time—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p:
A place of Priviledge and Liberty? a place of Debauchery, I le stand to't— what an age is this! that our Mother-Church shou'd have Loop-holes as well as the Laws! for those places of Liberty, as you stile 'em, serve only to Debauch our Children from their obedience; for when they have no mind to Marry the person of their Parents approbation, they run away with some indigent smooth-tongu'd Fellow to your place of Liberty (as you call it) and Marry him for Love forsooth, and commonly take their first tast of man in one of the Bawdy-houses, near that Church, and I'le stand
to't; I believe the Beds infect 'em, and make 'em turn Whores, and Cuckold their Husbands, as most do—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Must then my happiness be deferr'd till to morrow Sir?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Ay, indeed must it Sir, the rather too, because I have not perus'd the Deeds of settlement yet.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Here they are Sir, and the License too.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Very good, very good, let me see 'em.

div.stage: (Lov. gives Old M. the Writings, he peruses 'em. Enter Mrs. Mon. Betty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: I have perform'd my promise, your Daughter is within.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Oh Brother— I am obligd to you— now Mr. Loveall, you have nothing to do, but to prepare to be Marry'd to morrow— pray know this Gentleman, 'tis my Wifes Brother, a notable Wagg, I'le stand to 't— and he disguis'd himself on purpose in Petty-coats, to put a trick upon my Daughter, and cousen her into obedience— come, come, I know you are surpris'd, and think it is my Wife, he is so like her— embrace I say, embrace him, I'le stand to 't, you shall—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By Heaven his very Wife, for I know no Brother that she has— however, since she has brought Theodocia home, I'le favour her design, but I cannot imagine what will be the end of it— Sir, I must acknowledge the Obligation you have done me, in bringing fair Theodocia to be my Bride—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: But now I have her in my power Old Sir, I am resolv'd not to surrender her till I am assur'd of her Portion.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Thou art the notablest Lad I e're met with, but to satisfie you, I engage before ye all, to pay down on my Daughters Wedding day the Sum of Six Thousand Pounds; besides, it may be, a settlement of my whole Estate upon her and her Heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Done like a Father of so deserving a Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And I hope you'l say I do deserve your Daughter, when you shall see with what obliging kindness I shall use her— and my Uncle too has made a Settlement of his whole Estate upon me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: And you are resolv'd to give this Portion?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: As I say, I'le stand to't—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Stanly, bring forth your Bride—

div.p: See Sir, as to my own particular, I have kept my word; but my Friend here, has both won & Marry'd your Daughter, and now I hope the Portion will be ready—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: How! my Daughter Marry'd to that Hector? Brother—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Mistake not Sir, now my business is done, I resign that Title, and re-assume that of a dutiful Wife; and to say true, I never had a Brother.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Ha, is this true?— was it you then that wore the Breeches, and made me a Cuckold in my own House? y'are a Harlot, I'le stand to't, and I'le take a course with you, for I'le be Divorst if money and Law can do't; but first I'le cancel the Settlement I made on thee, of my Estate for Life, but it was with power of Revocation; and next, I'le turn that graceless wretch out of doors— 'tis well you have the modesty to hide that shameless Face—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Theodocia Marry'd!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: What will become of thee Laurence? for since thy Master has mist of the Mistress, thou art in danger of losing the Maid—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: Fret on Sir, yet 'twill not do, for your promise is good, the Portion must be paid, and Divorse when you will, the Prerogative-Court will give me Alimony, and the Chancery Separation money, enough to maintain a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: An absurd impudent Strumpet, I'le stand to't— but I am well enough serv'd for Marrying when I was past the use of Woman—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Was this the Assignation you made your Gallant, Madam?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: The very same Sir—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Even so will; for when I came, her kindness turn'd to this, and forc'd this Lady into my Armes to Marry, which you may be assur'd I did very unwillingly; but as you say— Persecution is come abroad, and we must suffer patiently—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Villain, thou never shalt enjoy her; thus I'le force a passage to thy soul, and cancel all those Vows y'ave newly made to this Lady—

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Now I have possession Sir, I shall not easily resign my Interest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Hold, hold, good Gentle-men, Murder not one another for me—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mrs. Essence!

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: Nay, then take heart of grace good Laurence, for there's hope agen; what Mrs. Essence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: The Milliner's Wife in Theodocia's Cloaths— then I must rest content, since I am out-witted

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: Curs'd Stars, am I Cousen'd then?

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Huswife, what have ye done with my Daughter? you have her Cloaths—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: Be not angry Mr. Monylove, she's gone about a certain Intreigue, and to carry it on, she desired my assistance: Now I, loving harmless witty Intreigues from my heart, readily comply'd, and I was thus disguis'd, and brought by Mrs. Luce to be Marry'd to a person in Mrs. Thodocia's name; and I Vow, me-thinks 'tis a very pleasant Intriegue.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: A Devil on your pleasant Intreigue, I am like to lose a fair Fortune by it; nothing Vexes me now, but that I did not perfect the Marriage, that in revenge, when the Cheat shou'd be discovered, I might have Hang'd thee for having two Husbands—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ess.
sp.p: I Vow Sir, I admir'd at your forbearance, & am glad you did not urge it on me, for I fear I shou'd have yielded, you Embrac'd me so passionately, and Kiss'd me so pleasantly!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: There's some hopes left, since she has mist of her design—

div.p: Joy, joy to you Stanly, you are the happy man to have a Fortune forc'd into your arms—
div.stage: Enter Cou. Theo. Luce, Betty, Tom Ess. after'em.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Well, I am Jealous agen, what a Devil shou'd my Wife do with Courtly now? something more is in it than I can at present apprehend— and what their business is here, for my blood I cannot guess—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: What, what do I see, Mr. Courtly and my Daughter together?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Who desire your Blessing, which is only wanting to compleat and crown our Joys—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then she's beyond all hopes, e're to be retriev'd—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Baggage, out of my sight—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Call my Wife names? that must not be— Neighbour forbear Ill-language, or look you, de'fee, the Law shall gagg you— what tho she be somewhat faulty, yet my Wife's my own Sir, and no one shall Correct her but my self— Ha, Mrs. Theo. in my Dolls Pettycoats?—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: What ayles the Fellow? shall not I Correct my own Daughter? if you want your Wife Sir, there she is, Marry'd to one of the Town-Hectors, I'le stand to't—

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Marry'd! Marry'd! oh insatiable! what, two Husbands! is this true? confess and be hang'd, for so thou shalt, if it be prov'd—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: In vain are all excuses; go, go, I'le never own you more, and your disobedience will justifie my intention, to give my Estate to Mr. Loveall in satisfaction for the affront you have done him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: First hear what I can say in Vindication of her actions— she cou'd not otherwise have done in Honour, her Vows by your command, being giv'n to her now Husband Mr. Courtly— but grant she had been free, yet Loveall cou'd not have Marry'd without the forfeit of his Honour; to prove the truth of which, read there the Accusation of his intended Perjury—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! this is the Widdow— too true, 'tis she, curse on her ill-tim'd presence— had I been sure of Theodocia, I'de have out-fac'd, nay, and out-ly'd the Devil before I'de have resign'd that beauteous Treasure— but now it is too late—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Do you not know me Sir? view me well— not yet know me?— to convince you, I am the person you have endeavour'd basely to abuse— see here— that Ladys Picture inclos'd Shows a Picture and a Letter to Lov. in your Uncles Letter, which by Providence you left hehind you at my house— now did I basely seek Revenge, thy Life is forfeited— but Love in me's more powerful— therefore to salve my Honour, you must— Marry me— if not—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am past evading it, nor indeed wou'd I, since I have lost Theodocia,— She's Rich and Handsome— Faith Madam I must plead guilty, I have been a very Villain,— but then consider Widdow, 'twas Love, all powerful Love of your sweet Self made me act so extravagantly; but if now thou prov'st kind-hearted and forgiv'st me, I'le proclaim thy mercy to the world, and Seal it in the next Church we come to—

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: What's here? a Contract of Marriage between William Lovett and Theodocia Landwell, of Stamford, Widdow; what is this to Mr. Loveall, Luce?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I confess it my hand, and intended for my name, but that my Uncle had provided your Daughter for my Wife— but since that does not succeed, I am resolv'd to execute what I then design'd only as a Cheat on this Ladys Virtue; Widdow, your pardon; Widdow, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: How! is Luce a Widdow?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes Sir, this is the Widdow who formerly I told you relieve'd me and my Man, when we were Rob'd and Stript.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: What a turn is this! a Rich Widdow my The's Maid? a good jest I'le stand to't.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Thus disguis'd, I gain'd admittance into this Lady's Service, to prevent my Disgrace, and her Ruin, as it might have prov'd; for, by my contrivance, both yours and your Daughters Honour is unsully'd, seeing she has perform'd her Vows to Mr. Courtly—

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: The Widdow! what Ill-luck was it that I did not get into my Masters Saddle.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: Y'are a Witty pretty, Pretty witty Widdow, I'le stand to't— Mr. Loveall— 'twas absurd, absurd in you to do so ill an action— however I'le stand your Friend to your Uncle, and as I say, Marry her, and I'le justifie it—

Mr. Courtly, take my Daughter, and bless ye together, and I hope you'le pardon my intention of Cousening you; I am Old Sir, 'twas for mony, a greater Estate, a greater Estate; and you know we Old men are as amorous on mony as you young Gallants on fair Maids; I'le stand to't, I am Sir, as I say I am.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: My Obedience Sir, for the future, shall shew my Forgiveness of your intended wrong, since I have full possession of my Theodocia.

sp.speaker: T. Essence to Stan.
sp.p: Pshaw, pshaw Sir, your reasoning is vain, do not I know the tricks of the Fashionable Wives, they make nothing of marrying their Gallants now a days, but I'le not allow it; you have marry'd her Sir, and shall keep her Sir, for I'le have nothing more to say to her; a fair riddance of her say I, and if she goes on marrying at this rate, the Town will be but one great forked head of her own making, upon Rep.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Essence, you must pardon your Wife, for what she did was at our request, and innocently done.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p: Pardon her? not I, therefore take her to you Sir, or I'le have her hangd Sir, and then I'le have the Five hundred pound Lass, whom I was inform'd had but three.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What she did, was at my desire Mr. Essence—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: To gain time for our marriage, and to prevent Mrs. Monyloves discovering us before our Joys were compleat.

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.p: A Pox upon't, it was too true; you may take your Jessamine butter-pot home, for any use I have made of her.

sp.speaker: Old M.
sp.p: I'le stand to't Neighbour Essence, she's a witty discreet Woman, and it will be absurd if you do not pardon her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. M.
sp.p: 'Twas only a harmless Intreigue, such as my Neighbour Tattle and I us'd when we went Maskt to the Galleries at the Play-houses, to hear the fine Gentle-men talk None-sence, and Swear, to be thought Witts— and this Gentle-man (if I am not deceiv'd) us'd to be one of 'em.

sp.speaker: T. Ess.
sp.p:
Say you so? then I'me satisfi'd, since Rep is whole agen— but Doll, provoke me no more to Jealousie; and doest hear, by way of prevention, go no more to the Play-Houses maskt; for there is a scurvey Proverb, and you may be caught at last— Your Pitcher may be crackt with often use— yet I will not bar you of your pleasure,
but be contented to go the seldomer, and I'le set you in a Box, as well as our Neighbours Wives; for the Pit and Galleries are become down-right Conventicles of Bawdery; one cannot hear a Play in 'em, for the Chattering of the fluttering Blades to a Company of Pockey-fac'd Creatures in Vizards, upon Rep— but Doll—

q.l: Use freedom with discretion, and you'le see

div.head: EPILOGUE, Spoke by Mrs. Essence.
div.l: NOw I had rather, Sirs, be hang'd, than come
To know your Curtesies about our Doom:
Y'ave been apply'd to, all the several ways
Man's Wit cou'd think of to procure your Praise,
Yet ne're has any yet successful been,
To gain your Favours, or Applauses win;
When monstrous Fools ye have been made o'th'Stage,
Such provocation justifi'd your Rage.
We've only now an Essence shewn— poor Man,
Whose Iealousie was Author of his pain,
But yet the Fop recover'd Rep again.
— But now me thinks a Cloak-Cabal I see,
Whose Prick-ears glow, whilst they their Iealousie
In Essence find— but Citty-Sirs, I fear,
Most of You have more cause to be severe:
We yield you are the truest Character.
But Tommy Swears by Rep— your Whoring lives
Are but too bad examples to your Wives.
If each man to his Dolly wou'd be true,
Then like my self, your's wou'd be honest too:
But, Sirs, I Vow it was with much adoe.
